tie up.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to tie someone’s arms, legs etc so that they cannot move
tie up.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The intruders tied Kurt up and left him.
tie up.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to fasten something together, using string, rope etc
tie up.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: He tied up all the old newspapers.
tie up.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to be very busy, so that you cannot do anything else
tie up.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: I can’t see you tomorrow – I’ll be tied up all day.
tie up.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to block a system or use it so much that other people cannot use it or it does not work effectively
tie up.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Don’t tie up the phone lines making personal calls.
Protesters tied up the traffic for three hours today.
tie up.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if your money is tied up in something, it is all being used for that thing and is not available for anything else
tie up.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: My money’s all tied up in the house.
tie up.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to finish arranging all the details of something such as an agreement or a plan
tie up.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: We’d better tie up the details with a solicitor.
tie up.translation[0].definitions[6].def: to be very closely related to something
tie up.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: The shortage of teachers is tied up with the issue of pay.
tie up.translation[0].definitions[7].def: to do the things that are necessary in order to finish a piece of work
tie up.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: I need to tie up a few loose ends before I go on vacation.
tie up.translation[0].definitions[8].def: to tie an animal to something with a rope, chain etc
tie up.translation[0].definitions[8].exa: She left the dog tied up to a tree.
tie up.translation[0].definitions[9].def: to tie a boat to something with a rope, chain etc
tie up.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: We tied up alongside a barge.
There was a boat tied up at the jetty.
tie up.translation[1].definitions[0].def: an agreement to become business partners
tie up.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: IBM’s tie-up with Auspex System Inc
tie up.translation[1].definitions[1].def: a strong connection between two or more things
tie up.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: the tie-up between class interests and politics
tie up.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a situation in which traffic is prevented from moving or there is a problem which prevents a system or plan from working
tie up.translation[2].definitions[0].def: to use money for something so that it is not easily available to be used for anything else
tie up.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: These securities could be a good choice for investors who can afford to tie up their money for two to seven years.
Her cash is all tied up in real estate.
The bank had too high a percentage of its assets, about 20%, tied up in one borrower.
tie up.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to use a telephone line so that it cannot be used for anything else or by anyone else
tie up.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: With broadband, your phone line will never need to be tied up again.
tie up.translation[2].definitions[2].def: to be very busy so that you do not have time to see someone or to do something
tie up.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: I can’t see you tomorrow — I’m going to be tied up all day.
tie up.translation[2].definitions[3].def: to finish arranging all the details of a contract, deal, or plan
tie up.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: Our sales team were able to tie up a new contract.
tie up.translation[2].definitions[4].def: to block the movement of vehicles or people so that they cannot move freely
tie up.translation[2].definitions[4].exa: There’s a free roadside service for stranded vehicles that tie up traffic.
tie up.translation[3].definitions[0].def: an agreement to become business partners
tie up.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: The company says that a tie-up with a foreign major is now on the cards.
